executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2023 currency. Parking lots and garages have struggled with diminishing revenue over the last few years as the outbreak of COVID-19 depleted economic activity and consumers' parking needs. The Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes throughout 2022 and 2023 has resulted in tightened budgets and decreased disposable income, suppressing demand for parking services at commercial facilities. Revenue has fallen at a CAGR of 5.1% over the past five years, and is expected to total $9.4 billion. A sharp decline in the world price of oil will contribute an estimated rise of 4.3% in 2023, when profit is projected to rise.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Economic Uncertainty and Shifting Consumer Preferences Boost Volatility in the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Economic uncertainty has led to a decline in car ownership as consumers seek cost-effective alternatives like ride-sharing and public transportation, reducing the demand for parking spaces. The hike in remote work and e-commerce popularity has substantially affected traditional retail businesses, reducing consumer parking demand as onsite shopping decreases in favor of online shopping. The Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes in 2022-2023 led to a budget squeeze and less disposable income. In response, demand for parking lots and garage services fell as individuals turned to cheaper, accident-avoiding transportation alternatives. Supply-chain disruptions resulting from the pandemic lead to a spike in the cost of a new or used car, contributing to lower rates of car ownership.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Management Contracts Gain Traction as Parking Companies Cut Costs
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Parking lot and garage companies increasingly use management contracts to streamline operations, reduce overhead, comply with regulations and avoid ownership or construction-related costs and work. Management contracts shift liability and operational risks away from a client to the contracted firm. Business owners can focus on their core operations without worrying about parking facility management challenges. Outsourcing parking services through management contracts has become more common as residential, commercial and manufacturing facilities seek to specialize in their own businesses. Nonresidential construction in urban areas has also boosted the popularity of management contracts, particularly in the context of mixed-use developments.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Technological Advancements Keep Consumers Out of Garages
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The development and adoption of self-driving cars have reduced travelers' reliance on parking. At the same time, electric vehicles and the rising popularity of ridesharing services like Uber and Lyft have emptied parking lots and garages.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumer Behavior Will Continue to Shift After COVID-19 Disruptions
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic facilitated a shift toward online shopping, reducing foot traffic to retail stores and mitigating the need for parking at commercial facilities like shopping malls and business districts. Online shopping will continue expanding since e-commerce platforms often offer a wider selection of products and services than physical stores and offer competitive pricing, incentivizing consumers to shop online instead of in-store. The pandemic also promoted remote learning and working, with many workplaces and educational facilities continuing to offer remote opportunities despite widespread vaccination. A reduction in commuter rates will leave parking lots emptier.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An Expanding Economy Bodes Well for Parking Companies
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The plummeting of oil prices will incentivize consumers to travel over the next five years. A surge in consumer confidence will encourage air and car travel, thereby spurring demand for parking services. A mild boost in construction activity will benefit parking companies, enabling them to expand when new commercial or residential facilities are constructed. The number of businesses is set to swell in the coming years, bolstering demand for parking lots and workplace garages. Total retail sales will rise as well, indicating demand from commercial markets. The world price of oil is set to fall consistently in the next few years, enabling car ownership among consumers who have less disposable income.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Alternative Transportation Modes Will Reduce the Need for Parking
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Integrating self-driving cars will accelerate the use of ridesharing services, keeping cars out of garages as they spend their days picking up and dropping off consumers, eliminating the need for their own vehicle. Consumers are increasingly advocating for safer bike lanes and bike-sharing programs to encourage environmentally friendly alternatives to driving in their communities. As environmental awareness grows, consumers will be more inclined to use public transportation and other alternatives to driving, reducing demand for parking services.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Parking service companies will adapt their business models to the changing technological landscape by incorporating automated parking services and electric vehicle accommodations, like charging ports.
Mobile Platforms Are Set To Shake Up Parking
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next few years, parking lots and garages will contend with mobile platforms that feed users information on transportation access, traffic patterns and parking access. Armed with more information, mobile app users will be able to choose alternative modes of transportation when traffic is heavy or compare prices across garages, boosting price competition. Some parking lot companies will use mobile apps to their advantage by integrating the platforms into their parking services, connecting drivers with available spots in real time. Garages will also embrace dynamic pricing made possible through mobile apps' data, enabling parking companies to inflate prices when demand is high.

industry_definition: This industry comprises operators with the primary function of providing parking and valet services at establishments on an hourly, daily or monthly basis. The industry mainly operates via management contracts, lease.

negative_impact_factors: low - steady Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: Management contracts have gained popularity among parking service operators seeking to cut costs in a highly competitive landscape. Through management contracts, parking operators can provide services without the burden of ownership or construction.

Alternative transportation modes will threaten parking operators over the next five years. Public transportation, ridesharing services and self-driving cars will steer consumers away from parking services.
Parking lot and garage operators receive little assistance. Pandemic-related assistance came from forgivable loans to smaller businesses, which mitigated the losses incurred in 2020.
Persistent declines in nonresidential construction limit business for parking operators. More than half of parking operators' sales are.
Economic uncertainty has temporarily reduced demand for on and off-street parking.
The use of technology and automation is threatening valet services.
Car-friendly regions like the West attract parking operators to the area.
The Southeast's high car ownership rates and large automotive market demand parking facilities.
Parking companies capitalize on new technologies to enhance their services.
Low barriers to entry promote the emergence of new parking facilities, which makes it harder for each business to differentiate itself.
Parking companies capitalize on new technologies to enhance their services.
Consumers are increasingly opting to pay for driving services rather than drive and park themselves.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Commercial businesses consist of privately operated businesses like commercial real estate, healthcare facilities, hotels, restaurants, sports and entertainment venues and privately owned city parking and parking lots.
The airport and airline market segment demands parking facilities. These are essential for travelers, pilots and flight attendants who need a secure parking space.
Industrial and high-tech manufacturing facilities require adequate parking facilities to accommodate employees, logistics and visitors for their day-to-day operations and business functioning.

Public schools, private schools, colleges and universities, all integral educational facilities, necessitate efficient parking facilities to accommodate students, staff and visitors for a seamless daily operation.

Commercial Building Construction in the US
Industrial Building Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The need for off-street parking falls when the economy slumps
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Off-street parking encompasses multiple services like hourly or daily options for quick visits, in-building or on-lot provision for weekly or monthly subscriptions and offering vehicle convenience and security.

Hourly and daily off-street parking is the most popular off-street parking service used by consumers who are shopping, dining or at an entertainment venue. The need for off-street parking fluctuates alongside broader economic conditions, like disposable income levels.

Valet services refer to attendants who park and retrieve customers' automobiles for a fee and are prevalent in restaurants, hotels, hospitals and medical centers. This segment has declined over the past five years as the pandemic hampered the hospitality sector.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Management fees grow in a cost-cutting environment
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment includes management fees associated with management contracts in which parking companies are paid a monthly base fee to manage and operate their clients' facilities. Management contracts require the least capital and no rental costs associated with the facility.

This segment includes meter collection, operation consultation and prepaid on-street parking services. On-street parking revenue is primarily directed toward municipalities, although parking companies frequently manage meter enforcement and collection operations for municipal government entities.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The USDOT controls the licensing and authorizations, safety and insurance requirements of parking lot shuttle buses. These regulations may stipulate that employees working in airports comply with drug and alcohol testing and undergo minimum training hours.

The ADA requires parking facilities to include handicapped spaces, headroom for wheelchair vans, attendants' booths that accommodate wheelchairs and elevators that are operable by disabled persons. The total number of accessible parking spaces required varies based on the size of a parking lot or garage.

Parking lot and garage operators need special licenses, with requirements varying by the municipality, to manage parking spaces. New York City requires a parking lot license for anyone holding five or more vehicles in an open space for a fee.

Health and safety guidelines were established in 2020 amid COVID-19. Such guidelines advised temporary social distancing and ongoing additional sanitation measures within facilities. Many of these guidelines have since been repealed.

basis_points.basis_title: Parking companies capitalize on new technologies
basis_points.basis_description: Parking companies capitalize on new technologies to enhance their services.
Consumers are increasingly opting to pay for driving services rather than drive.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Lofty wage costs for high-skilled labor
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Lofty wage costs for high-skilled labor can be a burden on new entrants.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Parking lot and garage operators need access to qualified employees to run parking facilities since the rising use of data analytics increases skill.

volatility_points.volatility_title: COVID-19 RESTRICTIONS SIGNIFICANTLY LIMITED GLOBAL TRAVEL
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for parking is typically stable; however, in 2020, business for parking companies plummeted. The cause was the COVID-19 pandemic, which left airports, educational facilities and commercial business districts desolate.

volatility_points.volatility_title: A LACK OF FREE PUBLIC PARKING EASES VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Airports, malls and other commercial businesses tend to be located in congested areas where free public parking isn't available. Drivers who frequent these places have no choice but to pay for private parking spaces.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.
The parking industry's demand for valet parking is decreasing as technology advances, like self-driving vehicles and automation, become more prevalent and consumer-preferred.

FAQs.question: What percent of revenue do you spend on advertising?
FAQs.answer: A relatively small percentage of industry revenue is dedicated to advertising. Consumers cannot readily tell the difference between industry services, making advertising less necessary in the industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer a referral rewards program to attract new customers?
FAQs.answer: Parking operators do offer reward programs to retain existing customers and may offer referral rewards for new customers.

FAQs.question: How does your company respond to fluctuations in demand? How have you responded to fluctuations in demand amid the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Many operators have responded to lower levels of demand amid the coronavirus pandemic by reducing operational expenses and furloughing employees.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in high-traffic areas to maximize visibility?
FAQs.answer: This is the best form of advertisement for parking lot operators.

FAQs.question: Is your company leveraging new technology, such as mobile phone applications, to streamline booking and communication with customers?
FAQs.answer: Apps like ParkWhiz enable customers to prepay for parking at a discount, while other apps like SpotHero promote exclusive deals with parking facilities.

FAQs.question: What data analytic programs does your company use to track company-wide sales?
FAQs.answer: Usage data and advanced analytics can help operators to optimize pricing strategies and streamline parking logistics.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: The industry is not particularly dangerous, so parking lot owners follow standard health and safety practices, educating employees on the standard practices. Operators incur substantial insurance costs, however, to cover potential damage to their facilities and customers' vehicles.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory changes related to the coronavirus pandemic significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Social distancing measures have sharply reduced demand for industry services amid the coronavirus pandemic, negatively affecting industry profit.

FAQs.question: How do you keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: Some companies are opting to invest in automation to reduce labor costs. Advanced data analytics can improve operational processes and therefore lower operating costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for the seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Companies may look to partner with events or complimentary businesses to reduce seasonal demand. Companies may also diversify their business lines to include management contracts, valet services and weekly or monthly parking to offset seasonality.

FAQs.question: How do you balance price rates to stimulate demand?
FAQs.answer: Consumers parking to commute or go to work are less price sensitive than those parking for leisure activities due to the necessity of employee parking. Strategically located garages in high-traffic areas tend to generate strong demand even with high prices.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation? Are you known for your reliability and performance?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators that compete for management contracts at public and private properties need to develop strong relationships with property owners to ensure the longevity of their operations. Operators that provide valet services must also emphasize the quality and reliability of their services.

FAQs.question: What do you do to promote loyalty? Do you offer special discounts or a high-caliber client experience?
FAQs.answer: A parking lot's customer base is usually local and may consist of commuters, making repeat customers important to the lot's success.

FAQs.question: How has your company been affected by changes in the price of crude oil? How has oil price volatility amid the coronavirus pandemic affected your business?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the world price of crude oil decreases demand for parking services. Volatility in the price of crude oil creates volatility in demand for parking garages, leading to less stable operating conditions.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor unemployment rates to plan your business accordingly? How has rising unemployment affected your business amid the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: A rise in unemployment decreases the number of drivers that commute to work, adversely affecting demand for parking services. The coronavirus pandemic caused a spike in unemployment, leading to significant losses for industry operators.

FAQs.question: Do you regularly monitor the number of businesses in the United States? How has the coronavirus affected demand from businesses?
FAQs.answer: As the number of businesses increase, demand for parking lots and garages increases as more businesses rent out office space. Amid the coronavirus pandemic, higher unemployment and work from home arrangements have hurt industry operators.
